question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
Let $P(x),$ $Q_1(x),$ $Q_2(x),$ $Q_3(x),$ $R(x)$ be polynomials such that
\begin{align*}
P(x) &= Q_1(x) (x + 2) - 13 \\
&= Q_2(x) (x^2 - 3x - 4) - 5x - 11 \\
&= Q_3(x) (x + 2) (x^2 - 3x - 4) + R(x),
\end{align*}and $\deg R(x) = 2.$  Find $R(x).$
inference:
Setting $x = -2$ in the first equation, we get
\[P(-2) = -13.\]Setting $x = -2$ in the third equation, we get
\[P(-2) = R(-2).\]Hence, $R(-2) = -13.$

Setting $x = 4$ in the second equation, we get
\[P(4) = -21.\]Setting $x = 4$ in the third equation, we get
\[P(4) = R(4).\]Hence, $R(4) = -21.$

Since $\deg R(x) = 2,$ $R(x)$ is of the form $ax^2 + bx + c.$  Then
\begin{align*}
4a + 2b + c &= -13, \\
16a + 4b + c &= -21.
\end{align*}Subtracting these equations, we get $12a + 2b = -8,$ so $6a + b = -4.$  Then $b = -6a - 4.$  Substituting into $4a + 2b + c = -13,$ we get
\[4a + 2(-6a - 4) + c = -13,\]so $c = -8a - 5.$  Hence,
\[R(x) = ax^2 + (-6a - 4) x + (-8a - 5) = \boxed{x^2 - 6x - 5}.\]
ground_truth:
Setting $x = -2$ in the equation $Q_1(x) (x + 2) - 13 = Q_3(x) (x + 2)(x^2 - 3x - 4) + R(x),$ we get
\[R(-2) = -13.\]Setting $x = 4$ and $x = -1$ in the equation $Q_2(x) (x^2 - 3x - 4) - 5x - 11 = Q_3(x) (x + 2)(x^2 - 3x - 4) + R(x),$ we get
\[R(4) = -31 \quad \text{and} \quad R(-1) = -6.\]Since $\deg R(x) = 2,$ we can let $R(x) = ax^2 + bx + c.$  Then
\begin{align*}
4a - 2b + c &= -13, \\
16a + 4b + c &= -31, \\
a - b + c &= -6.
\end{align*}Subtracting these equations in pairs, we get
\begin{align*}
12a + 6b &= -18, \\
3a - b &= -7.
\end{align*}Solving, we find $a = -2$ and $b = 1,$ so $c = -3.$  Hence, $R(x) = \boxed{-2x^2 + x - 3}.$

There might be an error in the solution above because of lack of understanding of the question. Please correct the error, if any, and rewrite the solution. Only output the final solution \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
inference:
The solution is correct. There is no error. 

The final answer is $\boxed{x^2 - 6x - 5}$.
ground_truth:
Setting $x = -2$ in the equation $Q_1(x) (x + 2) - 13 = Q_3(x) (x + 2)(x^2 - 3x - 4) + R(x),$ we get
\[R(-2) = -13.\]Setting $x = 4$ and $x = -1$ in the equation $Q_2(x) (x^2 - 3x - 4) - 5x - 11 = Q_3(x) (x + 2)(x^2 - 3x - 4) + R(x),$ we get
\[R(4) = -31 \quad \text{and} \quad R(-1) = -6.\]Since $\deg R(x) = 2,$ we can let $R(x) = ax^2 + bx + c.$  Then
\begin{align*}
4a - 2b + c &= -13, \\
16a + 4b + c &= -31, \\
a - b + c &= -6.
\end{align*}Subtracting these equations in pairs, we get
\begin{align*}
12a + 6b &= -18, \\
3a - b &= -7.
\end{align*}Solving, we find $a = -2$ and $b = 1,$ so $c = -3.$  Hence, $R(x) = \boxed{-2x^2 + x - 3}.$
